results.content:
I'll start by taking up a lot of time talking about cloud9 because that's what the course did.  The instructor goes on and on about it (I agree with Reed Owens' assessment on this) and the importance of matching development environments.  But when you try to use cloud9 you quickly find out it has become a part of AWS since the course was published.

Now you can still use cloud9 if you set up an AWS account (Cloud9 is free for a year, you set up EC2 environments in place of workspaces), but I don't recommend it unless you have other uses for AWS.  If you have access to a decent shell you're better off using that.  A local environment will be fine.

With what little course is left, the instructor does do a nice little introduction to jasmine and and some of it's capabilities.

Overall, this course is an opportunity wasted.  There's a real need for a quality  introductory course on jasmine which includes a good discusssion on unit testing.  This course unfortunately lost focus early on didn't provide much of use.  Honestly, if I hadn't missed my window I would have asked for a refund at the beginning of the cloud9 discussion.
results.content_html:
I'll start by taking up a lot of time talking about cloud9 because that's what the course did. The instructor goes on and on about it (I agree with Reed Owens' assessment on this) and the importance of matching development environments. But when you try to use cloud9 you quickly find out it has become a part of AWS since the course was published.

Now you can still use cloud9 if you set up an AWS account (Cloud9 is free for a year, you set up EC2 environments in place of workspaces), but I don't recommend it unless you have other uses for AWS. If you have access to a decent shell you're better off using that. A local environment will be fine.

With what little course is left, the instructor does do a nice little introduction to jasmine and and some of it's capabilities.

Overall, this course is an opportunity wasted. There's a real need for a quality introductory course on jasmine which includes a good discusssion on unit testing. This course unfortunately lost focus early on didn't provide much of use. Honestly, if I hadn't missed my window I would have asked for a refund at the beginning of the cloud9 discussion.

results.content:
Very well explained, and easy to understand. I am not sure why this course does not have a better rating!

The only improvement I can think of is to provide an example of the nested describe function in a real web application.

results.content:
A well bottom-up explanation of the Jasmine unit testing.
Also there is a good real-world example that is build with a right explanation, with 'how-to-does' and the 'why's'.
results.content_html:
A well bottom-up explanation of the Jasmine unit testing.
Also there is a good real-world example that is build with a right explanation, with 'how-to-does' and the 'why's'.

results.content:
Hardly learned anything of use in this course.  The author spends way too much time advertising Cloud9 and it's environment. 

Granted that Jasmine is fairly simple, the author doesn't spend time on any but the basic matchers, nothing about spys, etc.

Code in the example, while basic is horrible and doesn't help understand how to use Jasmine in my environments.  There were lots of coding mistakes, misspellings (Hellow).  Majic changes between sections, etc.  The whole course needs to be redone.  It's like watching paint dry watching the "coding" being done on the screen in real time.   It's the first time I've never had to pause a class to get my coding done.  I found myself done and waiting for the instructor.

What you learn from this class:
* How to use Cloud9
* Why Cloud9 is the instructors choice.
* Setups instructions in Cloud9 that don't work anymore (npm has trouble with the current node version) -- Defeats the entire reason the author wants to use Cloud9
* What is NPM... Did I say how to use Cloud9...
* Oh 1/3 through the class and your about to use Jasmine, the instructor says you don't need to use Cloud9...

What is actually learned on Jasmine
  * How to setup Jasmine in a project
  * The Describe/it methods
 * Nested Describe/it methods
 * Hooks and nested Hooks
 * expect with examples of toContain, toEqual, not, isLessThan, etc.
results.content_html:
Hardly learned anything of use in this course. The author spends way too much time advertising Cloud9 and it's environment.

Granted that Jasmine is fairly simple, the author doesn't spend time on any but the basic matchers, nothing about spys, etc.

Code in the example, while basic is horrible and doesn't help understand how to use Jasmine in my environments. There were lots of coding mistakes, misspellings (Hellow). Majic changes between sections, etc. The whole course needs to be redone. It's like watching paint dry watching the "coding" being done on the screen in real time. It's the first time I've never had to pause a class to get my coding done. I found myself done and waiting for the instructor.

What you learn from this class:
* How to use Cloud9
* Why Cloud9 is the instructors choice.
* Setups instructions in Cloud9 that don't work anymore (npm has trouble with the current node version) -- Defeats the entire reason the author wants to use Cloud9
* What is NPM... Did I say how to use Cloud9...
* Oh 1/3 through the class and your about to use Jasmine, the instructor says you don't need to use Cloud9...

What is actually learned on Jasmine
* How to setup Jasmine in a project
* The Describe/it methods
* Nested Describe/it methods
* Hooks and nested Hooks
* expect with examples of toContain, toEqual, not, isLessThan, etc.

results.content: Could have had more focus on test driven development, writing tests before writing code.
results.content_html: Could have had more focus on test driven development, writing tests before writing code.

results.content: lectures 5 and 6 - arguably the most import - refuse to play on either my ipad pro or my ipad mini.  I had hope to learn this while on the train in the mornings.  Please fix, since I have already paid.  Thank You
